question: Question_Section_102_07_(a)
statement:
Decide whether or not the following statement is true or false. If true,
give a proof. If false, give a counterexample.

\textbf{(a)} The product of two orthogonal matrices is orthogonal.
sols:
This statement is \textbf{true}.

\emph{Proof:} Let \emph{P} and \emph{Q} be orthogonal matrices, in
particular, \emph{P\textsuperscript{T}P = PP\textsuperscript{T} = I},
\emph{Q\textsuperscript{T}Q = QQ\textsuperscript{T} = I}. Let $S = PQ$
Since the matrices \emph{P} and \emph{Q} are orthogonal, this means that
the vectors are real. This means that $P^* = P^T$

Then

\begin{align*}
S^TS &= (PQ)^TPQ \\
&= Q^TP^TPQ \\
&= Q^TIQ \qquad \text{since P is orthogonal} \\
&= Q^TQ  \\
&=I
\end{align*}

Similarly, $SS^T$ = $PQ(PQ)^T$ = $PQQ^TP^T$ = $PIP^T$ = $PP^T$ = $I$

$\therefore S^TS = SS^T = I$ and the product of two orthogonal matrices
is also orthogonal.
hints:
Suppose you have two orthogonal matrices and argue directly from the
definition of what it means for a matrix to be orthogonal.

A matrix \emph{P} is orthogonal if

$\displaystyle PP^{T} = I$
